p: The first dose is generally given as part of a routine vaccination program. With the Expanded Program on Immunization and the Measles Vaccine Initiative, coverage in many developing countries has improved. In developed countries, the second dose is generally given at school entry. In resource-poor countries, the most effective delivery has been through mass campaigns or national immunization days, a strategy pioneered by the Pan American Health Organization ( Moss and Griffin, 2006). These campaigns target large proportions of the population, quickly interrupt endemic measles virus transmission and are credited with a steady decrease in the annual mortality due to measles. If campaigns are not repeated every 3â€“4 years, susceptible individuals will build up and measles will again become endemic as virus is inevitably imported from countries with continued measles transmission.
